You are required to create a Python function, `parse_gatk_command`, which takes a string representing a command for running GATK (Genome Analysis Toolkit) and extracts important information from it. The GATK command will always follow the pattern:

```
baseq-SNV run_gatkpipe -1 <forward_reads> -2 <reverse_reads> -n <sample_name> -g <genome_reference> -d <output_directory>
```

Where:
- `<forward_reads>` is the file name of the forward reads in fastq format.
- `<reverse_reads>` is the file name of the reverse reads in fastq format.
- `<sample_name>` is the name of the sample being analyzed.
- `<genome_reference>` is the reference genome being used for analysis. It will be one of `'hg38'`, `'hg19'`, or `'mm10'`.
- `<output_directory>` is the directory where the output of the GATK analysis will be saved.

The function should return a dictionary with the following keys:
- `'forward_reads'`: The file name of the forward reads.
- `'reverse_reads'`: The file name of the reverse reads.
- `'sample_name'`: The name of the sample.
- `'genome_reference'`: The reference genome being used.
- `'output_directory'`: The directory where the output will be saved.

Assume that the command will always be in the correct format and all arguments will be present.

Function Signature: `def parse_gatk_command(command: str) -> dict:`

3. `buffer_size` (usize): The size of the buffer.

The macro should perform the following steps:
1. Declare a static variable with the given `buffer_name` and `buffer_type`.
2. The static variable should be assigned an array of size `buffer_size` of the desired type `buffer_type`.
3. Initialize the array elements to their default values.

You need to modify the macro to ensure that the buffer is initialized correctly and that the correct type is used.

Your task is to complete the macro `create_static_buffer` with the necessary code.

Note:

Assume the input values are valid and that the `buffer_type` is a valid Rust type name.

This is an npm package called "MatrixMath". This package was written a long time ago, when typescript was not yet created. However, today, this package is used in a project where typescript is used, and this package is missing the `matrixMath.d.ts` file. Produce the data type typescript file for the package:

Usage
-----

The module is created in the CommonJS format, exporting using module.exports, meaning you need a CommonJS require system to use it. It is published in npm, so including it in node.js is simple:

Install it in the command line:

```
npm install matrixmath

```

Then include the module in your code:

```
var Matrix = require('matrixmath/Matrix');

```

[](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#api)API
---------------------------------------------------

### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#overview)Overview

Constructor

- new Matrix(opt\_rows, opt\_cols, opt\_setInitial)

Instance properties

- rows
- cols
- length

Static methods

- add (matrix, matrix1[,...matrixN])
- subtract (matrix, matrix1[,...matrixN])
- multiply (matrix, matrix1[,...matrixN])
- divide (matrix, matrix1[,...matrixN])

Instance methods

- setIdentityData ()
- setEmptyData ()
- setData (data, opt\_rows, opt\_cols)
- getData ()
- toArray ()
- toLogString ()
- copy (matrix)
- clone ()
- add (matrix[,...matrixN])
- subtract (matrix[,...matrixN])
- multiply (matrix[,...matrixN])
- divide (matrix[,...matrixN])
- power (number)
- transpose ()
- invert ()
- getDeterminant ()
- equals (input)
- isIdentity ()

### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#constructor)Constructor

Create a new Matrix instance by using the constructor:

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#new-matrix)new Matrix()

```
var matrix = new Matrix();

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#new-matrixopt\_rows-opt\_cols)new Matrix(opt\_rows, opt\_cols)

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 0 0
 0 1 0
 0 0 1
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#new-matrixopt\_rows-opt\_cols-opt\_setinitial)new Matrix(opt\_rows, opt\_cols, opt\_setInitial)

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3, false);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 undefined undefined undefined
 undefined undefined undefined
 undefined undefined undefined
]

```

\* \* \* \* \*

### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#instance-properties)Instance properties

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixrows)matrix.rows

The rows property contains the number of rows in the matrix.

```
> console.log(matrix.rows);
3

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixcols)matrix.cols

The cols property contains the number of columns in the matrix.

```
> console.log(matrix.cols);
3

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixlength)matrix.length

The length property contains the number of values in the matrix.

```
> console.log(matrix.length);
9

```

\* \* \* \* \*

### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#static-methods)Static methods

The following methods will return a new Matrix instance.

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixaddmatrix1-matrix2matrixn)Matrix.add(matrix1, matrix2[,...matrixN])

Creates a new matrix with the sum of the passed in matrices. All matrices must have the same size. If a matrix is found that is not the same size, it is skipped.

```
var matrix = Matrix.add(matrix1, matrix2);

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixsubtractmatrix1-matrix2matrixn)Matrix.subtract(matrix1, matrix2[,...matrixN])

Creates a new matrix with the difference of the passed in matrices. All matrices must have the same size. If a matrix is found that is not the same size, it is skipped.

```
var matrix = Matrix.subtract(matrix1, matrix2);

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixmultiplymatrix1-matrix2matrixn)Matrix.multiply(matrix1, matrix2[,...matrixN])

Creates a new matrix with the product of the passed in matrices. All matrices must either be square and of the same size, or the next matrix in line must have the same number of rows as the number of columns in the previous result.

The first argument must be a matrix instance, but the rest can be either matrices or numbers. If a number is seen, a scalar multiplication is made.

```
var matrix = Matrix.multiply(matrix1, matrix2);
// or
var matrix = Matrix.multiply(matrix1, 3);

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixdividematrix1-matrix2matrixn)Matrix.divide(matrix1, matrix2[,...matrixN])

Creates a new matrix with the quotient of the passed in matrices. All matrices must be square and of the same size.

```
var matrix = Matrix.divide(matrix1, matrix2);

```

\* \* \* \* \*

### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#instance-methods)Instance methods

The following methods are available on all Matrix instances.

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixsetidentitydata)matrix.setIdentityData()

Set the data in the matrix to the identity matrix.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3, false).setIdentityData();

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 0 0
 0 1 0
 0 0 1
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixsetemptydata)matrix.setEmptyData()

Set the data in the matrix to be only zeros.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3, false).setEmptyData();

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 0 0 0
 0 0 0
 0 0 0
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixsetdatadata-opt\_rows\_-opt\_cols)matrix.setData(data, opt\_rows\_ opt\_cols)

Set the data in the matrix to the passed in data.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3);
matrix.setData([1, 2, 3, 4], 2, 2);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 2
 3 4
]

```

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3);
matrix.setData([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 2 3
 4 5 6
 7 8 9
]

```

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3);
matrix.setData(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 2 3
 4 5 6
 7 8 9
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixgetdata)matrix.getData()

Get the data in the matrix as an array with extra data.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.getData());
[1, 0, 0, 1]
> console.log(matrix.getData().rows);
2
> console.log(matrix.getData().cols);
2

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixtoarray)matrix.toArray()

Get the data in the matrix as an array.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toArray());
[1, 0, 0, 1]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixtologstringopt\_indentation-opt\_separator-opt\_start-opt\_end)matrix.toLogString([opt\_indentation[, opt\_separator[, opt\_start[, opt\_end]]]])

Get the data for this matrix as a formatted string, which is useful for logging and debugging. It will be formatted with line breaks to visualize the rows and columns.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 0 0
 0 1 0
 0 0 1
]

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString(5));
[
 1 0 0
 0 1 0
 0 0 1
]

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString(' ', ' | '));
[
 1 | 0 | 0
 0 | 1 | 0
 0 | 0 | 1
]

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString(0, ' | ', '-- start --', '-- end --'));
-- start --
1 | 0 | 0
0 | 1 | 0
0 | 0 | 1
-- end --

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixcopymatrix1)matrix.copy(matrix1)

Copies the data from another matrix into the original matrix.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2);
var matrix1 = new Matrix(2, 2, false).setData(1, 2, 3, 4);
matrix.copy(matrix1);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 2
 3 4
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixclone)matrix.clone()

Returns a new matrix with the same content as the first one.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2);
var matrix1 = matrix.clone();

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixaddmatrix1matrixn)matrix.add(matrix1[,...matrixN])

Adds all the matrices into the original matrix. All matrices must have the same size as the original one. If a matrix is found that is not the same size, it is skipped.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(1, 3).setData(1, 2, 3);
var matrix1 = new Matrix(1, 3).setData(2, 4, 6);
matrix.add(matrix1);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 3 6 9
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixsubtractmatrix1matrixn)matrix.subtract(matrix1[,...matrixN])

Subtracts all the matrices from the original matrix. All matrices must have the same size as the original one. If a matrix is found that is not the same size, it is skipped.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(1, 3).setData(1, 2, 3);
var matrix1 = new Matrix(1, 3).setData(2, 4, 6);
matrix.subtract(matrix1);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 -2 -2 -3
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixmultiplymatrix1matrixn)matrix.multiply(matrix1[,...matrixN])

Multiplies all the matrices into the original matrix. All matrices must either be square and of the same size, or the next matrix in line must have the same number of rows as the number of columns in the previous result.

The arguments can be either matrices or numbers. If a number is seen, a scalar multiplication is made.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(1, 2, 3, 4);
var matrix1 = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(2, 4, 6, 8);
matrix.multiply(matrix1);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 14 20
 30 44
]

```

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(1, 2, 3, 4);
matrix.multiply(3);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 3 6
 9 12
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixdividematrix1matrixn)matrix.divide(matrix1[,...matrixN])

Divides all the matrices from the original matrix. All matrices must be square and of the same size as the original matrix.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(1, 0, 0, 1);
var matrix1 = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(2, 0, 0, 2);
matrix.divide(matrix1);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 0.5 0
 0 -0.5
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixpowernumber)matrix.power(number)

Raises the matrix to the the given power.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(1, 2, 4, 1);
matrix.power(3);

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 25 22
 44 25
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixtranspose)matrix.transpose()

Transposes the matrix.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(1, 2, 4, 1);
matrix.transpose();

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 1 4
 2 1
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixinvert)matrix.invert()

Inverts the matrix.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3).setData(
 3, 0, 2,
 2, 0, -2,
 0, 1, 1
);
matrix.invert();

```

```
> console.log(matrix.toLogString());
[
 0.2 0.2 0
 -0.2 0.3 1
 0.2 -0.3 0
]

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixgetdeterminant)matrix.getDeterminant()

Gets the determinant of the matrix. The matrix must be square for this to be possible. If it's not square, this will return `null`.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(4, 6, 3, 8);
var determinant = matrix.getDeterminant();

```

```
> console.log(determinant);
14

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixequalsmatrix1)matrix.equals(matrix1)

Tests if the matrix has the same content as another matrix. Returns `true` if it has, `false` otherwise.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 2).setData(3, 0, 2, 0, 0, 1);
var matrix1 = new Matrix(3, 2).setData(3, 0, 2, 0, 0, 1);
var matrix2 = new Matrix(2, 2).setData(3, 0, 2, 0);

matrix.equals(matrix1); // true
matrix.equals(matrix2); // false

```

#### [](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#matrixisidentity)matrix.isIdentity()

Tests if the data of the matrix represents the identity matrix. Returns `true` if it is, `false` otherwise.

```
var matrix = new Matrix(3, 3);
var matrix1 = new Matrix(3, 3, false).setData(1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1);
var matrix2 = new Matrix(3, 3, false).setData(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9);

matrix.isIdentity(); // true
matrix1.isIdentity(); // true
matrix2.isIdentity(); // false

```

`\
`

[](https://www.npmjs.com/package/matrixmath#versioning)
-------------------------------------------------------

How would you refactor this function?
'''
def find\_remapped\_server\_content(site\_list=None):
 """
 Returns a list of previously-synced content from the server
 - those fixlets/tasks/baselines/computergroups with 'x-bfsync-source-id' tags

 TODO - filter to only the sites we are updating now? Or no? It's a use-case question
 If we only sync one site now, with Baselines in it, which source fixlets do we want to update for the Baseline?
 This could also be a real problem with custom copies of a synced fixlet into other sites....
 """
 global config, session, server\_metadata
 url=config["url"]
 source\_actionsite=server\_metadata["actionsite\_url"]
 site\_filters=[]

 if site\_list is None:
 site\_filters=['( True )']
 elif isinstance(site\_list, list):
 if len(site\_list) ==0 :
 site\_filters=['( True )']
 #site\_filter='name of it is contained by set of ("' + '"; "'.join(site\_list) + '")'
 
 for site in site\_list:
 if site=="actionsite":
 site\_filters+=["( master site flag of it ) "]
 elif site.split("/",1)[0]=="custom":
 site\_filters +=[f'( custom site flag of it and name of it = "{site.split("/",1)[1]}" )']
 elif site.split("/",1)[0]=="operator":
 site\_filters +=[f'( operator site flag of it and name of it = "{site.split("/",1)[1]}" )']
 else:
 warnings.warn(f"find\_synced\_server\_content: failed to determine target site type for {site}")
 else:
 raise ValueError(f"find\_synced\_server\_content: site\_list must be a list or None")
 
 site\_filter=" OR ".join(site\_filters)

 query=f"""
 ( id of it
 , name of site of it
 , mime fields "x-bfsync-source-id" of it
 , mime fields "x-bfsync-source-modification-time" of it
 , modification time of it
 , (if custom site flag of it then "custom" else if operator site flag of it then "operator" else "") of it
 ) of fixlets whose (
 mime field "x-bfsync-source-actionsite" of it = "{source\_actionsite}"
 ) of all bes sites whose ( {site\_filter} )"""

 data={"relevance": query, "output":"json"}
 response=session.post(url=url + '/api/query', data=data)
 if not response.ok:
 raise ValueError("Failed to retrieve existing synced fixlets from the target server, aborting")
 
 else:
 response\_json=json.loads(response.text)
 response\_results=response\_json["result"]
 result\_set=[
 { "site\_type": element[5]
 , "sitename": element[1]
 , "id": element[0]
 , "source-id": element[2]
 , "source-modification-time": element[3]
 , "modification-time": element[4]
 } for element in response\_results
 ]
 return result\_set
'''

Hold it Dao-n Oneseco Media             I held a vote and right now Black people don't trust DAO or anything related to a community because gathering in public usually ends with police showing. Our history makes cynicism and refusal to be one big easy target a survival trait handed down from generation to generation. Black people born in America never got to see Black people united like African and Haitians. Division kept our labor cheap, uprisings down and power non-existent.      So this Web3 community push seems lost on the culture, but we were built for this and don't know it yet. Our history is full of us developing our societies within American society specifically for us like Black clubs, Black barbershops, Black beauty salons. Our mothers traded knowledge that kept us fed on shoe string budgets (fried food kept longer) and our leaders were made in secret least they be targeted. Our hood is one big "Decentralized Autonomous Organization" with its own economy and justice in spite of America's society.      Our secret societies were demonized, our ways seen as savage, until they were copied and made mainstream. Been that way since the dancing in juke joints was seen as savage and deviant until Elvis, backwards hats was seen as thuggish and ghetto at first, before "bling" was in a Zales commercial, it was seen as the reason why Black people stay impoverished and Lil Wayne complained about it in a song. I'm old enough to remember when rap was evil and the cause of the crack epidemic. Eminem is compared to Elvis for a reason.  The Cool Factor  This leads me to Black Twitter, you see in 2009, Twitter was barely getting celebrities to buy into it. 3rd party apps were allowed to keep developers as users. Then Black people like me used the open space to promote our podcasts, developed fans and networked as a community. We did things like fake RT, set a community standard that after midnight explicit tweets were allowed and our network grew. Mobile app developers created an entire market around it.      Live tweets? We used to call it "watching a show as a family". Our reaction to Game of Throne's Red Wedding episode, my favorite Black Twitter event ever, made that show a global phenomenon. My Game of Thrones shirt that I wore to a beach party got a lot of attention from female book fans that saw their fandom get a credibility boost. The ladies I attended the party had to pull me away and later joked that "Pam" was two drinks away from asking to see my dragon. By the season finale of the show, the author had to write a new book for the new audience and HBO's spinoff is on it's 3rd episode as I type this.      Black Twitter: Influence goes Global      Black Twitter made Empire, Blackish, Scandal and Black Jesus ratings juggernauts. Marvel's Civil War movie saw Black Twitter choose sides with hashtags and #TeamCap claiming victory. #TeamCap also claims credit for the scene with Black Panther and Captain America in Avengers: Endgame. HBO's Insecure's star used to be the Insecure Black Girl account on Black Twitter. Quinta Brunson also went from the TL to her own sitcom. Black Panther became a such a global phenomenon that Marvel's rival DC still hasn't recovered. Captain America's portal scene with Black Panther in Endgame was their thanks to the culture for some. DC looked so uncool and white that Batman roast sessions were common on Twitter.     Black Lives Matter sentiment hit Batman who was seen as an overzealous cop and a privileged rich white kid they couldn't relate to instead of the caped crusader who targeted anonymous thugs and supervillains. Black Twitter's roast sessions were acknowledged in a Batman movie, DC's best PR move.    Black Twitter: Unpaid Innovators      Now imagine all of our creativity that made networks rich being harnessed and sold as a community with payment automatically distributed according to contribution and each transaction down to the penny being publicly available. Rap labels without the embezzlement or bad contracts, equal pay for men and women, no Black leaders or religion, and a win for one is a win for all. My viral video just gave the community more promotion and more eyes for your music label who's album cover was part of an NFT collection that is more valuable now for all the token holders.      Class is video and audio based with 5 minutes being seen as too long. Not only does graduation increase your skills, your cap can also be used as a coupon for discounts and a badge to post on Facebook to make mama proud. "Decentralized" as in segregated and secured networks like your home Wifi, not like your phone company's network. "Autonomous" just means we rule and sustain our own people and "Organization" means we're a collective, a community, a Metaverse gang with our own hood that we built and own ourselves. Discord is Marshall Mathers, Sony is Dr. Dre signing him to Interscope as Slim Shady. Social media is Bubba Sparx. Madden is 50 Cent.

Here is a piece of text: Pentagon officials are considering whether to keep U.S. troops along the southwest border an additional 45 days, potentially extending a controversial mission to assist the Border Patrol into next year, U.S. officials said.
The 5,800 troops now deployed in California, Arizona and Texas are scheduled to depart Dec. 15. But the Department of Homeland Security, parent agency of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, has opened discussions with the Pentagon about delaying their departure until late January, according to an official who was not authorized to speak on the record.
If approved, the extension would represent another expansion of the military border operation, whose scope has steadily grown since President Trump rushed troops to border posts in Arizona, Texas and California shortly before the Nov. 6 midterm election.
An extension would keep troops away from home through the Christmas and New Year’s holidays, which would intensify criticism of the operation from Democrats, who have called the operation wasteful and unnecessary.
Only last week, the White House authorized troops along the border to detain, search, and if necessary use deadly force to protect other U.S. government personnel, a major change in the military role but one that Pentagon officials insisted would only be employed in dire emergencies.
Thousands of migrants are in the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Mexicali. Some clashed earlier this week at the San Ysidro border crossing with Border Patrol agents, who fired tear gas to prevent them from seeking to rush the border en masse. Unarmed U.S. troops were seen moving razor wire to block the attempted crossing.
If the mission is extended, one official said, the Pentagon could rotate new troops to the border and send some personnel who have been living in makeshift camps since October back to their home bases.
The Defense Department has sought to keep tight limits on the border operation. At the same time, other administration officials who advocate aggressive efforts to block immigration have sought to expand the military role to buttress the president’s incendiary charges that caravans of migrants moving north through Mexico pose an imminent threat to U.S. security.
The Homeland Security department has not made a formal request for an extension, Pentagon officials said.
Defense Secretary James N. Mattis told reporters Wednesday the two departments were in discussions about whether an extension was required.
Mattis added that the troops had largely completed their original mission of strengthening protections with razor wire fences and vehicle barriers at dozens of legal border crossings, known as ports of entry.
That could lead commanders of the operation to send home engineering and logistics troops who have been installing the additional barriers. Military police who would be called on in case of a riot or other large-scale attempt to cross the border would likely remain, along with support troops, helicopter units and other specialized troops.
It’s unclear whether the overall size of the force would shrink if an extension were approved.
Mattis played down the possibility that troops could be involved in use of force against migrants, saying the Border Patrol had shown its capability of securing the border without direct involvement by troops.
Mattis did not address why the troops would need to stay on the border if the Border Patrol could handle security.

Based on the text material above, generate the response to the following quesion or instruction: Can you provide a summary of the potential extension of U.S. troops along the southwest border and the reactions it has received from Democrats?

Generate response to the question/instruction based on a piece of given material

Question/Instruction: Can you summarize the main idea of the text "Does Fort Hood Have Meaning?"

Given material: Does Fort Hood Have Meaning?
[T]o ignore the circumstances of this particular shooting would be like saying Oswald was just some random wacko whose actions occurred in a total vacuum, that the Cold War, his Marxist sympathies, the fact that he lived in the Soviet Union for a time, were all basically irrelevant. They weren't. And while the are are many things we don't yet--and may never--know about Nidal Malik Hasan and what drove him to commit such an evil act, we can't ignore the things we do know. If only because, by ignoring them, we allow others, like Malkin and her ilk, to try to define them for us.

What is the author looking forward to this summer and how does the author hope to share their experience with others interested? Answer according to: The first week has brought many great experiences. This week we have caught about 8 fish and about 10 eels at the Charles River in the morning classes. The kids enjoy being able to fish on the Charles River. Every time they catch fish you can just see the excitement and the pride in their smile. A young girl got the chance to hold an eel for the first time ever then encourage others to do the same.
At community boating the kids are interested in anything they can get there hands on. When seeing all the eels the kids all tried to hold one but it was difficult because of the slimy skin the eels have but with practice they have become great teachers for younger children.
This summer is going to be a blast! I cannot wait to meet new people and find new creatures in the Charles River. We are having lots of fun and hope to share the experience of the eels with others interested!
